urn:contentItem:6D0F-2G91-JBMY-H2HK-00000-00Determinants of Visitors’ Willingness to Pay for Enhanced Ecosystem Services in Mudumalai Tiger Reserve, Tamil Nadu, India: A Contingent Valuation Approach2025-11-15T07:49:08Z2025-11-15T07:49:08ZLexisNexisPg. 443-474Determinants of Visitors’ Willingness to Pay for Enhanced Ecosystem Services in Mudumalai Tiger Reserve, Tamil Nadu, India: A Contingent Valuation Approach

Declaration of Conflicting InterestsThe author(s) declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

FundingThe author(s) received no financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

Rajkumar VBoopathi SABSTRACT

This study examined the factors influencing visitors’ willingness to pay for improved ecosystem services through the conservation of the Mudumalai Tiger Reserve (MTR) in the Nilgiris District, Tamil Nadu, India. The MTR plays a crucial role in providing and protecting various ecosystem services. However, it is vulnerable to negative externalities and drivers of ecosystem change, which affect the quality and quantity of ecosystem services, leading to the loss of valuable ecosystem services. To address this issue, it is necessary to understand the adverse effects of externalities and drivers of ecosystem change, as well as to consider people’s preferences. To investigate the factors influencing visitors’ willingness to pay for enhanced ecosystem services in MTR, this study used a dichotomous choice-contingent valuation method and a logit regression model. The study found that 64% of visitors expressed concern about mitigating adverse impacts and were willing to provide financial support. The results of the logit regression analysis further revealed that factors such as family size, respondent education, monthly family income, environmental awareness, and bid price significantly influenced visitors’ willingness to pay. To enhance ecosystem benefits and address the challenges in tiger conservation within the reserve, our study suggests that several measures need to be implemented, including prioritizing education, awareness, the mitigation of human–wildlife conflict, and income-linked and dynamic pricing strategies.

FULL TEXTIntroduction

Protected areas are crucial in global conservation efforts, covering approximately 17% of the Earth’s land (Raphela & Duffy, 2022; Sinha et al., 2009; UNEP-WCMC & IUCN, 2021). These areas are highly desirable destinations for nature-based tourism, offering unique biological, natural, and cultural features (Ceballos-Lascuráin, 1996; Rasal et al., 2021; Whitelaw et al., 2014). They also significantly contribute to local and national economies as a major sector of the global tourism industry (Archabald & Naughton-Treves, 2001; Balasubramanian, 2022; Nyaupane & Poudel, 2011; Raphela & Duffy, 2022). In the Indian context, protected areas are classified into different types, including 106 National Parks, 567 Wildlife Sanctuaries, 220 Community Reserves, and 105 Conservation Reserves, covering 5% of the country’s land (National Wildlife Database, 2023). These areas serve as critical habitats for a remarkable diversity of life, providing shelter for over 45,000 plant and 91,000 animal species (Post & Pandav, 2013; Raphela & Duffy, 2022; Rastogi et al., 2013). The establishment of these legally designated areas emphasizes their pivotal role in preserving ecosystem functions, conserving genetic resources, and protecting biodiversity (Abell et al., 2007; Keith, 2000; Kingsford & Nevill, 2005; Mancini et al., 2005; Ninan & Kontoleon, 2016; Roux et al., 2008; Verma et al., 2017).

Tiger reserves are exceptionally significant among protected regions, serving as the last refuge for the world’s largest felid species. They also act as umbrella species, indirectly benefiting various ecosystems and their inhabitants (Dinerstein et al., 2007; Karanth & DeFries, 2011; Richard Damania et al., 2003; Udaya Sekhar, 2003; Vucetich et al., 2015; Walston et al., 2010). The role of tiger reserves goes beyond the conservation of this iconic species; they are integral to preserving biodiversity, protecting landscapes, sustaining food chains, regulating ecological processes, and conserving habitats for numerous other species. This helps maintain natural evolutionary processes in the wild (Jhala et al., 2014; Karanth & DeFries, 2011; Udaya Sekhar, 2003; Vucetich et al., 2015; Walston et al., 2010). Furthermore, these protected areas provide a wide range of tangible and intangible ecosystem services to human society. They play a crucial role in generating employment, offering essential fodder, supporting fishing activities, providing valuable bamboo and fuelwood resources, yielding non-timber forest products, supplying water sources, purifying water bodies, sequestering carbon, regulating climate, protecting gene pools, preserving cultural heritage, and holding spiritual value for communities (Jhala et al., 2010; Mishra, 1997; Udaya Sekhar, 2003; Verma et al., 2017). These multifaceted benefits underscore the profound significance of protected areas in promoting ecological integrity and human well-being. According to the Millennium Ecosystem Assessment (2005), tiger reserves offer various ecosystem services, including provisioning, regulating, cultural, and supporting services. Provisioning services include tangible resources such as fodder, fuelwood, non-timber forest products, water provision, and employment opportunities for local communities. Regulating services involves the benefits derived from ecosystem processes, including carbon sequestration, soil conservation, pollination, climate regulation, and carbon storage. Cultural services provide intangible benefits, such as recreational opportunities. Supporting services underpin the production of all other services, including gene-pool protection and nutrient retention.

Tiger reserves play a crucial role in safeguarding diverse wildlife habitats while also providing ecosystem services that benefit individuals and society in multiple ways (Badola et al., 2010; Chaudhry, 2016; Ninan & Kontoleon, 2016; Verma et al., 2017). As apex predators, tigers contribute significantly to maintaining ecological balance and conserving biodiversity. Tiger conservation is morally significant and has substantial economic value, as demonstrated by various studies. For example, Badola et al. (2010) estimated the annual economic value of the Corbett Tiger Reserve to be US$167,619, primarily through recreational benefits and an impressive $63.6 million through carbon-reduction services. The study also assessed provisioning services such as firewood (valued at US$7,346 per day), fodder (valued at US$5,290 per day), timber, and other non-timber forest products. Another study by Chaudhry (2016) in the Pakke Tiger Reserve in Arunachal Pradesh, India, estimated annual flow benefits worth Rs. 8.25 billion and stock worth Rs. 144.30 billion, highlighting its substantial economic, social, and cultural contributions. Similarly, Das and Dutta (2019) evaluated the economic value of provisioning services in the Laokhowa and Burhachapori Wildlife Sanctuaries in Assam using the market price method, estimating it to be 8.7 million rupees. Rasal et al. (2021) determined that the Kailadevi Wildlife Sanctuary in Rajasthan provides various flow services with an annual economic value of Rs. 84.47 billion. These services include carbon sequestration, fuelwood, soil loss avoidance, soil nutrient retention, groundwater recharge, water storage, fodder, pollination, gene pool preservation, habitat maintenance, biological control, gas regulation, religious tourism, and waste assimilation. The sanctuary’s total stock services were valued at Rs. 367.3 billion, considering carbon and timber stock.

In Balasubramanian’s (2022) study, the economic value of ecosystem services in the Biligiri Rangasawmy and Nagarhole national parks in Karnataka was assessed to be 52.61 million rupees. The highest value was carbon sequestration at 29 million rupees, followed by recreation services at 7.8 million rupees, provisioning services at 3.6 million rupees, and soil erosion prevention at 2.18 million rupees. Another study by the Indian Institute of Forest Management (IIFM) in 2019 evaluated the economic value of ten tiger reserves in India. These reserves include Anamalai, Bandipur, Dudhwa, Melghat, Nagarjunsagar Srisailam, Pakke, Palamau, Panna, Similipal, and Valmiki Tiger Reserves. According to the study, these reserves generate annual economic benefits of 16.202 billion rupees. The estimated human resources values range from 1643 billion to 7042 billion rupees. Furthermore, the reserves possess substantial wood and carbon resources valued at 96.745 billion rupees. The protection provided by the reserves against diseases, predators, and parasites was valued at 7.7 crore and 24.15 million rupees, respectively (Verma et al., 2019).

Economic Valuation of Mudumalai Tiger Reserve

The Mudumalai Tiger Reserve is a critical conservation resource with numerous rare species. Understanding the economic value of ecosystem services is essential for appreciating its significance. Srinivasan and Kaushal (2020) conducted a groundbreaking estimation of the ecological services produced by the MTR, valuing them at approximately Rs. 14,650 crores annually. These services encompass climate regulation, valued at Rs. 932.10 crores per year, and health and well-being benefits from the forests, worth nearly Rs. 7,000 crores. In addition to the ecosystem services, non-marketed services such as recreational benefits also hold economic significance. Rajkumar and Boopathi (2022) quantified the recreational value of the MTR using the Individual Travel Cost Method, estimating it to be Rs. 114.26 million per annum. This underscores the reserve’s role in providing opportunities for people to connect with nature and enjoy its recreational offerings. However, despite the valuable ecosystem services and recreational benefits provided by tiger reserves such as Mudumalai, they face significant threats and challenges to their conservation. These challenges include agricultural encroachment, major infrastructure and industrial developments (such as railways, roads, mines, irrigation, and power projects), increasing exploitation of rural communities, and demand for medical cures and tiger body parts in decorative items. Addressing these threats is crucial for preserving these valuable natural resources and the ecosystem services they provide.

Negative Externalities and Drivers of Ecosystem Change in the MTR

Recognizing and valuing ecosystem services is crucial for addressing the challenges posed by negative externalities and drivers of ecosystem change in MTR. The economic perspective underscores the significance of preventing the reduction or loss of ecosystem services to mitigate issues related to market failure, public goods, and negative externalities (Helm & Hepburn, 2014). Despite its numerous valuable attributes, MTR has experienced adverse effects from various activities. This section will delve into the primary negative externalities and drivers of ecosystem change affecting MTR’s ecological balance, the loss of ecosystem services, and tiger conservation efforts.

Forest Fires

Forest fires in the MTR have become a recurring and pressing concern, particularly during the summer months (Chandran, 1997; Cochrane, 2003; Gadgil & Chandran, 1988; Kellman et al., 1996; Kodandapani et al., 2004). These fires threaten the region’s diverse biodiversity and disrupt the delicate soil dynamics (Certini, 2005; Verma & Jayakumar, 2012). Numerous studies have focused on forest fires in the MTR, including investigations by Kodandapani et al. (2004, 2008, 2009), Srivastava et al. (2014), Mondal and Sukumar (2014), and Verma and Jayakumar (2015). For instance, Verma et al. (2015) conducted a comprehensive analysis of forest fires in the MTR from 1999 to 2014, revealing an annual fire rate of 3141.46 ha per year, with an average of 22 fire incidents annually and an annual increase rate of 9.78%. In addition, Verma et al. (2017) investigated the effects of forest fires on tree diversity and regeneration in MTR, highlighting the importance of understanding the ecological impact on the area’s flora, fauna, and soil ecology. Their research found that burnt plots exhibited decreased tree diversity in the 2 and 5 year-old areas, whereas regeneration showed a positive trend. These findings underscore the necessity of monitoring and managing forest fires in the Mudumalai Tiger Reserve to preserve its biodiversity and ecosystem. The primary causes of these fires have been identified as human activities, including tourism, settlements in and around the reserve, antler collection, and poaching (Srivastava et al., 2014; Verma et al., 2015, 2017).

Human–Elephant Conflict

The MTR in Southern India is renowned for its large population of elephants, estimated at 6,000 (Williams et al., 2020). However, these elephants face numerous threats, including habitat loss, conflicts with human activities, poaching, and degradation at local and regional levels. Several studies have focused on the human–elephant conflict (HEC) in the reserve. Ashokkumar et al., (2021) conducted a study in 14 villages within the reserve from November 2006 to March 2008 and documented 297 incidents of crop damage. Additionally, it reported that between 1998 and 2008, seven people were killed and six injured in elephant attacks. Over the years, the overall crop damage decreased from 2.1% in the early 1990s to 0.98%. This study found that the peripheral areas experienced higher levels of damage (1.51%) than the center of the village. Data on crop species, elephant damage, protection methods, and land-use changes related to HEC were collected through direct enumeration and questionnaire surveys (Ashokkumar et al., 2021). Another study discussed elephant harvest rates as a management tool for controlling human–elephant conflict through culling. This study highlighted the variability in survey data and the inaccuracies in transition probabilities, cautioning against relying on them for deterministic modeling. The results indicated that both habitat and the presence of human settlements significantly influenced elephant habitat use on a landscape scale (Baskaran et al., 2007; Puyravaud et al., 2016).

Lantana Camara

Lantana camara, an invasive weed, has numerous negative effects on the ecosystem in the Mudumalai Tiger Reserve. It has spread across large areas, affecting plant species in the reserve. Approximately 280 square kilometers out of the total 321 square kilometers are covered by Lantana camara (Wilson, Gruber, et al., 2014). Moreover, this plant is not a suitable food source for Asian elephants, which affects their habitat use (Kumar et al., 2012). Invasive plants like Lantana camara have the potential to disrupt ecosystem function, impede natural regeneration, hinder natural succession, displace native species, and threaten biodiversity (Gotmare & Kimmatkar, 2019; Raphela & Duffy, 2022). A restoration project demonstrated that removing Lantana had no detrimental effects on the richness or composition of native plant communities. Instead, it increased the species richness of the understory plants (Wilson et al., 2013). Wilson, Gruber, and Lester (2014) investigated whether Lantana camara was associated with variations in elephant foraging behavior in the Mudumalai Tiger Reserve. This study indicated that Lantana camara is a widespread exotic invasive species in India, capable of dominating and displacing native forage species. It has also been found that Lantana camara invasion negatively affects the foraging behavior of elephants in reserves (Kumar et al., 2012). Assessing the effect of Lantana invasion on natural regeneration and soil properties in two forest types (dry and moist deciduous) of Mudumalai Tiger Reserve, Rashmitha et al. (2023) found that Lantana invasion harms soil properties, which is likely due to high nutrient extraction. The study also revealed that Lantana invasion can disrupt ecosystem function and natural regeneration (Raphela & Duffy, 2022). Numerous researchers have warned that tiger populations could decline within the next five years if effective measures are not implemented to eradicate this invasive species from the wild (Gotmare & Kimmatkar, 2019; Kumar et al., 2012; Raphela & Duffy, 2022; Wilson et al., 2013).

Linear Infrastructure (National Highway)

National highways that pass through natural reserves threaten wildlife by increasing the risk of roadkill. Mudumalai Tiger Reserve, located at the intersection of three southern states—Karnataka, Kerala, and Tamil Nadu—is affected by various linear infrastructure elements, including an interstate national highway (National Highway 181) that cuts through it. This highway causes significant disturbance to wildlife within the area. Research studies have demonstrated the negative impact of this linear infrastructure on MTR, resulting in the death of endangered species such as tigers, leopards, sloth bears, leopard cats, small Indian civets, and gaurs due to vehicular traffic (Baskaran & Boominathan, 2010; Daniel et al., 1995; Desai & Baskaran, 1998; Gokula, 1997). A study conducted in the Mudumalai Tiger Reserve recorded 180 roadkill incidents between December 1998 and March 1999, involving 40 species of amphibians, reptiles, birds, and mammals. Amphibians were the most affected (53%), followed by reptiles (22%), mammals (18%), and birds (7%). The study suggests implementing flyovers, speed limits, speed breakers, and signposts along the highways to mitigate these wildlife mortalities. Another study conducted in the same reserve documented the killing of 497 three-striped palm squirrels along the Udhagamandalam to Masinagudi state highway, spanning 40 km, between January 2014 and December 2016 (Samson et al., 2020). This study highlighted the significant threat to the three-striped palm squirrel population from the current 0.09 roadkills/km rate. In addition, a study assessing the tiger corridor between Mudumalai Tiger Reserve and Mukurthi National Park in Nilgiri Biosphere Reserve, India, emphasized the importance of corridors in wildlife conservation and biodiversity (Baranidharan et al., 2020). However, the anthropogenic influence on the tiger corridor between Mudumalai Tiger Reserve and Mukurthi National Park poses a major threat to wildlife (Baranidharan et al., 2020).

Given the significant threats to above, there is a risk of compromising the ecological benefits and cultural values of the MTR. Given the severity of these threats, it is crucial to take immediate action to balance the MTR’s significant ecological and cultural roles with the potential development of a tiger-centric tourism industry. The negative externalities and drivers of ecosystem change associated with these challenges require urgent attention from conservationists and policymakers. Their aim should be to effectively preserve the MTR and enhance its ecosystem services to avoid the potential loss of these invaluable ecological contributions. To achieve this, institutional initiatives in the form of proper policies and management of the MTR and robust public support are essential. Recognizing the public as a crucial stakeholder in the MTR, collaboration with the government is imperative to ensure conservation efforts. Such collaboration is critical because of the potential threats posed by public interventions and because any conservation initiative requires financial backing and active public involvement to be most effective. In this context, the user-pays principle assumes significance.

The User-Pays Principle

Investments in protected areas, such as tiger reserves, are essential for sustaining ecological and food security, promoting ecosystem benefits, creating employment, supporting local economies, and contributing to long-term societal development (Chaudhry et al., 2016). However, reports of insufficient compensation to address the negative outcomes of conservation implementation extend beyond India to various countries (Ravenelle & Nyhus, 2017). Many nations require assistance in prioritizing conservation spending (Bruner et al., 2004), and government funds in developing countries may need to be increased to address all national priorities. Consequently, funding allocated to wildlife conservation in most countries tends to be modest compared with available resources, raising concerns about the sustainability of ongoing financial support (Nyhus et al., 2003). Conservation programs focused on large predators, such as tigers, incur significant costs (Dickman et al., 2011). In India, recreational sites within tiger reserves are considered public goods, and the general budget covers their maintenance costs through Project Tiger. However, numerous tiger reserves need help to generate sufficient revenue to cover management costs, resulting in a continuous decrease in net conservation funds. Notably, in the recent union budget (2021–2022), silkworms received more funding (Rs. 875 crore) than tigers (Rs. 250 crore), and the budget for Project Tiger has experienced a reduction of Rs. 100 crores over the past two years. Despite these challenges, potential options to meet the financial needs of protected areas have been identified, including a market-based approach involving resource user fees, payment for ecosystem services, and bio-prospecting charges (Emerton et al., 2006). Therefore, in addition to dedicated government expenditures, alternative mechanisms aligned with the user-pays principle deserve consideration to safeguard the MTR, prevent the loss of ecosystem services, and enhance its overall ecological contributions. Considering the above discussions, this study aims to comprehensively understand the ecosystem services associated with the conservation of MTR and explore the factors influencing visitors’ willingness to pay for improved ecosystem services in the reserve.

Material and MethodsStudy Area

The Mudumalai Tiger Reserve is an important protected area located in Tamil Nadu in the Nilgiris district of the Western Ghats (latitude: [11°20′ N]; longitude: [6°30′ E]). The name “Mudumalai” comes from Tamil and refers to an ancient hill range believed to be approximately 65 million years old. This reserve holds immense ecological significance as it is not only the first biosphere reserve established in India but is also recognized as one of the 25 globally important biodiversity areas. In April 2007, the Tamil Nadu State Government designated Mudumalai as a tiger reserve due to its remarkable population of tigers. According to The Status of Tigers 2022 report released in April 2023, the tiger population in the Mudumalai Tiger Reserve in Tamil Nadu, India, was estimated to be 162. The reserve spans 321 km2 and shares borders with adjacent natural sanctuaries and divisions, including the Wayanad Wildlife Sanctuary in Kerala to the west, the Bandipur Tiger Reserve in Karnataka to the north, the Nilgiris North division to the south and east, and the Gudalur Forest Division to the southwest. The MTR is situated at the tri-junction of three southern states—Karnataka, Kerala, and Tamil Nadu—it boasts a rich and diverse landscape (see Maps 1 and 2).Map 1.Location of Mudumalai Tiger Reserve, Tamil Nadu, Western Ghats.Map 2.Mudumalai Tiger Reserve, Tamil Nadu, administrative zone.

The land-use and land-cover status of the Mudumalai Tiger Reserve has evolved due to various factors, including conservation initiatives, climate, and human activities. Detailed studies on land-use changes, forest cover dynamics, and alterations in vegetation patterns have been conducted, contributing to a deeper understanding of the ecological transformations within the reserve. For instance, research conducted by Turner et al. (2015) highlights the impact of conservation policies, whereas studies by DeFries et al. (2010) emphasize the role of climate in shaping land-use changes. Additionally, the works of Hansen et al. (2013) and Lambin and Meyfroidt (2011) provide valuable insights into the effects of human activities on the reserve’s land cover. Collectively, these studies contribute statistical data and analysis that enhance our comprehension of the changing landscape in the Mudumalai Tiger Reserve.

The climatic conditions in Mudumalai exhibit seasonal variations. The reserve experiences a moderate climate, with cold temperatures in December and early January and warmer weather in March and April. Detailed climatic records, including temperature, precipitation, and humidity, have been maintained over the years, aiding in the analysis of climate trends and their potential impact on the reserve’s ecosystem. The reserve includes valuable timber resources such as Teak (Tectona grandis) and Rosewood (Dalbergia spp.). It is also rich in endemic plants like Elephant grass (Dichanthium annulatum) and giant bamboo (Dendrocalamus strictus). Ongoing studies on the flora in the reserve provide insights into plant biodiversity, ecological roles, and changes in vegetation composition over time. The diverse habitat of Mudumalai supports several wildlife, including tigers (Panthera tigris), elephants (Elephas maximus), Indian gaurs (Bos gaurus), mongooses (Herpestidae), spotted deer (Axis axis), wild dogs (Cuon alpinus), mouse deer (Tragulidae), jungle cats (Felis chaus), common langurs (Semnopithecus entellus), barking deer (Muntiacus muntjak), hyenas (Hyaenidae), and Malabar giant squirrels (Ratufa indica). In addition, it boasts an impressive avian population, with over 260 bird species, including endangered species such as the Malabar grey hornbill (Ocyceros griseus) and the pied hornbill (Anthracoceros coronatus) (Gotmare & Kimmatkar, 2019).

Sampling Technique and Data Collection

As a popular wildlife tourism destination in Tamil Nadu, the Mudumalai Tiger Reserve offers various recreational activities, including vehicle rides, elephant safaris, and visits to elephant camps (Baskaran et al., 2010; Gokula & Vijayan, 1996; Rajkumar & Boopathi, 2022). A primary survey was conducted using a purposive sampling technique for this specific study. A total of 372 visitors participated in the survey, and data were collected through face-to-face interviews using an interview schedule that included all relevant information and important variables. Following the recommendations of the NOAA panel for Contingent Valuation Method (CVM) studies, data collection involved direct face-to-face interviews, which are considered more reliable and trustworthy than self-administered surveys.

Garrett Ranking Technique

The Garrett ranking technique is used to identify the most important environmental problems faced by the Mudumalai Tiger Reserve. In this technique, visitors rank the various environmental issues, and these rankings are converted into scores using a specific formula. The scores are then used to determine the most important issue. The formula used in the Garrett ranking technique is as follows:Percent position=100 (Rij− 0.5)Nj

Rij = Rank given for the ith variable by the jth visitor.

Nj = Number of variables ranked by the jth visitor.

The estimated percentage position is converted into scores using Garrett’s table. The scores for each problem are then added for each individual, and the total and mean scores are calculated. The problem with the highest mean score is deemed the most important. This technique is employed to prioritize the environmental and ecological problems faced by the MTR based on visitor perceptions. This study addresses the most significant issues identified through this method.

Conceptual Framework

Tiger reserves play a vital role in providing a range of ecosystem services, including opportunities for ecotourism. However, many of these services do not have a market price, which makes it challenging to determine their economic value (Whittington, 2002). To address this issue, various economic valuation methods have been developed, such as revealed and stated preference methods, which help in assess the economic value of non-marketed goods for conservation purposes (Carson, 2000). While there are ongoing debates about the accuracy of these methods, stated preference methods offer several advantages over revealed preference methods in welfare analysis (Carson, 2012; Hanley et al., 2003; Hausman, 2012; Johnston et al., 2017). As a result, policymakers have increasingly relied on stated preference methods to evaluate the economic benefits of ecosystem services and determine the costs associated with environmental protection, such as reducing poaching and improving water quality (Hanley et al., 2003; Johnston et al., 2017).

The contingent valuation method is a widely recognized and commonly used stated preference method due to its simplicity, comprehensibility, and flexibility (Bateman & Langford, 1997; Bharali & Mazumder, 2012; Birdir et al., 2013; Carson, 2000; Hoyos & Mariel, 2010; Lee & Han, 2002; Mmopelwa et al., 2007; Reynisdottir et al., 2008; Venkatachalam, 2004). Numerous studies have demonstrated that a well-designed CVM measure based on stated preferences yields more reliable and valuable results (Birdir et al., 2013; Carson, 2000, 2012; Reynisdottir et al., 2008; Venkatachalam, 2004). Additionally, CVM is used to assess environmental threats and estimate the monetary value of ecosystem services, particularly in relation to habitats and cultural services.

Theoretical Background

The contingent valuation survey typically uses direct questions to determine respondents’ maximum willingness to pay for the protection of environmental resources, the presence of specific environmental characteristics (such as biodiversity or ecosystem health), and the influence of covariates on their willingness to pay. These questions are guided by the principle of utility maximization (Haab & McConnell, 2002; Nijkamp et al., 2008; Venkatachalam, 2004). The CVM is built upon the theory of consumer behavior, which provides a strong foundation for understanding the economic value of ecosystem services and environmental benefits. Specifically, the CVM uses an indirect utility function to determine the maximum amount an individual is willingness to pay (WTP) for benefits, such as the conservation of a specific resource. This function considers the individual’s income (M) and the quantity of the good (Q) available, allowing them to optimize their utility by consuming non-market products derived from the environmental good. The utility function can be represented as follows:(1)U (X,Q)where X represents vector market goods, the individual’s problem of maximizing Utility (U) within a budget constraint,(2)PX=M

We can examine how consumers respond to price changes when p is a vector of market prices and Q represents the solution as a collection of Marshallian demand functions.(3)Xi (P,M;Q)

Based on the above equation, the CVM uses indirect utility functions to build its framework,(4)Vi(P,M;Q):∀i

Suppose a policy change is made, and there is an improvement from Q0 to Q1. In this case, the CVM measures the compensating surplus an individual (represented by i = 1, 2, 3, ….,N) is willing to pay to maintain the same level of compensated utility.(5)Vi(P,M;Q)=Vi(P,Q1,M−WTP)

The individual’s WTP for enhanced ecosystem services can be expressed as follows:(6)WTPi=m(P,Q1,U0)− M(P,Q0,U0)=P {H(P,Q1,U0)− H(P,Q0,U0)}

The expenditure function (m) and the Hicksian compensated demand function (H) are essential components of the CVM. These functions play pivotal roles in determining the WTP for environmental improvements. They are based on the fundamental assumptions of utility maximization and consumer preference axioms. The expenditure function (m) quantifies the trade-offs that individuals are willing to make between their income and the environmental improvements they desire. It serves as a fundamental indicator, capturing the monetary amount an individual is willing to invest or spend to attain a specific level of utility. Understanding this function is crucial in evaluating how individuals value environmental resources and their associated benefits. On the other hand, the Hicksian compensated demand function (H) provides insights into the quantity of a particular environmental good or service that an individual is willing to purchase at different prices. This helps us analyze how changes in the price of environmental improvements influence consumer choices and preferences. By studying this function, we can better understand how individuals allocate their resources to maximize utility while considering the costs associated with environmental enhancements.

Researchers and policymakers employ these functions to gain a deeper understanding of individuals’ preferences and economic decisions regarding environmental improvements. These functions are based on the idea that individuals are willing to pay for any increase in utility that aligns with their preferences and enhances their well-being. This framework offers a quantitative means of assessing individuals’ WTP for environmental enhancements, providing valuable insights for informed decision-making processes related to resource conservation and environmental management.

Model Specification for the CVM

When conducting research using CVM frameworks, the choice of survey format is crucial. One commonly used format is the dichotomous choice (DC) format, which is popular because it reduces hypothetical bias and elicits more accurate responses (Arrow et al., 1993; Carson & Groves, 2007). The DC format is preferred over the open-ended format, which has been criticized for its lack of realism and tendency to generate numerous protest bids, making it difficult to accurately estimate WTP (Arrow et al., 1993; Lockwood & Tracy, 1995; Mmopelwa et al., 2007). In this study, we used the dichotomous choice-contingent valuation method to investigate the factors influencing visitors’ willingness to pay for improved ecosystem services through the conservation of the MTR. When analyzing the relationship between WTP and explanatory variables using regression models, it is important to address potential issues such as heteroscedasticity, non-normality of the error term, and the risk of estimated probabilities falling outside the range of 0–1 (Mohd-Rusli et al., 2009).

A linear probability model can be used as an alternative to the Ordinary Least Squares (OLS) regression model. However, logit and probit models are commonly preferred when applying econometric methods to analyze CV survey data. Both models ensure that estimated probabilities remain within the range of 0–1 and capture non-linear relationships with the explanatory variables (Fix & Loomis, 1998; Loomis, 1987). However, the key difference between these models lies in the distributional assumptions of the error terms. The logit model assumes a different error term distribution, while the probit model assumes a normal distribution (Hornung & Keasler, 2014). Therefore, the logit model, often referred to as the logit regression model, is the most suitable and frequently used method for estimating WTP by predicting a binary outcome based on independent variables and the probability of an event occurring (Hanemann, 1994; Loomis et al., 1997). Therefore, we used the logit regression model in this study to identify socio-economic, demographic, and environmental factors influencing visitors’ dichotomous WTP behaviors. Equation (7) in this study utilizes the logit cumulative distribution function (CDF) within the logit model to calculate the likelihood that the ith visitor will agree to pay for the conservation of the MTR.(7)Prob (Y=1 | X)=F ( Xi,b′)=P i=ezi1+ezi.=11+e−zi.Zi is a linear function of n explanatory variables (Xi) and is expressed as follows:Zi=β0+β1X1i+β1X1i+β2X2i+β3X3i+…+βnXni

Now we can write,WTP=logit(P)=ln (Pi1−Pi)=ln (1+ezi.1+e−zi.)=ln ( ezi)=Ziwhere Pi/(1-Pi) is the “odds ratio” or the ratio of the probability that a household is willing to pay for the conservation of the MTR to the probability that a visitor is not.

If the error term (ε) is also considered, the logit model becomes as follows:(8)WTP=ln (Pr (yes)1−Pr (yes))=Zi=β0+β1X1i+β1X1i+β2X2i+β3X3i+…+βnXni+ε

Considering the above discussion, a logit model is constructed to identify relevant factors that affect the WTP of visitors.WTP=ln (Pr (yes)1−Pr (yes)) =β0−β1 age+β2 family size+β3respondent education+β4family income+β5 environmental awarness−β6 bid price+εIn this model, WTP is the dependent variable that indicates the willingness to pay the proposed bid. It takes on a binary value, where WTP = 1 if the respondent answers “yes” and WTP = 0 otherwise. The presence of the random disturbance term (ε) acknowledges the inherent variability in human responses and accounts for unexplained factors that affect WTP decisions. The coefficients (β1, β2, …, βn) represent the influence of each explanatory variable (X1, X2, …, Xn) on the log-odds of agreeing to pay for conservation. Positive coefficients indicate that an increase in the corresponding explanatory variable increases the likelihood of agreeing to pay, while negative coefficients suggest the opposite. By estimating these coefficients through the logit regression model, we can quantitatively assess the impact of various factors on visitors’ dichotomous WTP behaviors, shedding light on the drivers of conservation support and facilitating evidence-based decision-making in the context of resource conservation and environmental management.

Explanatory Variables and Expected Signs in the Logit Regression Model

Our analysis incorporates three categories of explanatory variables: quantitative, binary, and categorical. The quantitative variables in our study include age, family size, respondent education, monthly family income, and bid price. Notably, the bid price represents the monetary amount in rupees that respondents are willing to contribute. Furthermore, we include binary variables, such as gender and environmental awareness, as explanatory factors in our analysis. These binary variables provide valuable insights into the underlying factors influencing visitors’ willingness to pay. For a comprehensive description of the explanatory variables used in our model, please refer to Table 5, which provides a detailed overview of each variable.

In Table 1, the “Expected Sign” column indicates the anticipated direction of the relationship between each variable and visitors’ willingness to pay. For instance, a positive sign implies a positive correlation, indicating that as the variable increases, the willingness to pay also increases. Conversely, a negative sign suggests an inverse relationship, indicating that as the variable increases, WTP decreases. This framework guides our understanding of the potential impact of each variable on visitors’ willingness to pay for the conservation of the Mudumalai Tiger Reserve.Table 1.Descriptions of the Explanatory Variables Employed in the Logit Regression Model.

Results and DiscussionSocio-Demographic and Economic Characteristics of the Respondents

Examining the socio-demographic and economic attributes of the respondents is crucial for understanding their perspectives and behaviors in conservation efforts. This information provides a snapshot of the surveyed population and helps identify patterns and factors that can influence attitudes and actions. In this study, we thoroughly analyze the socio-demographic and economic profiles of the respondents to gain insights into how their backgrounds shape their awareness, attitudes, and willingness to contribute to the conservation of the Mudumalai Tiger Reserve.

Tables 2 and 3 provide a comprehensive overview of the socio-demographic and economic characteristics of the respondents. The majority of respondents are male, accounting for 85.8%, while females make up the remaining 14.2%. Geographically, over 60% of respondents live in urban areas, 22% in semi-urban areas, and 15.6% in rural areas. In terms of marital status, 71.2% of respondents were married, with 26.9% being single. Family structures reveal that 13.7% live in joint families, while the majority (86.3%) reside in nuclear families. In relation to age distribution, over 65% of respondents are below 41 years old, 21.3% fall between 41 and 50 years old, and the remaining 11% are above 50 years old. The average age of the respondents was 37 years. Occupation-wise, 54% of respondents were employed in the government or private sectors, 34.1 % are engaged in self-employed/business activities, and 11.8% were classified as manual laborers (coolies). In terms of monthly family income distribution, nearly 41% earn between Rs. 9000 and Rs. 45000, 21.5% earn between Rs. 45001 and Rs. 65000, 17.5% earn between Rs. 65001 and Rs. 85000, and 20.4% earn above Rs. 85000. The average monthly family income is Rs. 64,721.77. Family-related metrics included an average family size of 3.93 members and an average of 15.43 years of respondent education. Notably, respondents traveled an average distance of 201.49 KM to reach the MTR, providing insights into the geographical spread of the surveyed population and their commitment to engaging with conservation efforts in the MTR.Table 2.Socio-Demographic and Characteristics of the Respondents.Table 3.Descriptive Statistics of the Respondents.

Awareness and Attitudes of Respondents Toward Conservation

The imperative for environmental conservation and sustainable management of biodiversity-rich areas is indisputable for the well-being of ecosystems and the species they support. In this context, understanding public awareness, attitudes, and willingness to contribute financially (WTP) toward conservation efforts is paramount. This study focuses on the Mudumalai Tiger Reserve, delving into respondents’ awareness of environmental issues, attitudes toward conservation, and willingness to financially support the enhancement of ecosystem services.

Table 4 provides insights into respondents’ awareness of environmental issues and the loss of ecosystem services, coupled with their willingness to pay for enhanced ecosystem services in the Mudumalai Tiger Reserve. Notably, 60.2% of the surveyed respondents demonstrated awareness of ecological and environmental concerns, while 39.8% indicated a lack of awareness regarding such issues and the potential loss of ecosystem services. To deepen our understanding of respondents’ attitudes toward broader environmental issues and the protection of forests and wildlife within the MTR, we employed a three-point scale comprising “not interested,” “somewhat interested,” and “very much interested” categories. The findings revealed that 67.7% of respondents expressed a strong interest in safeguarding and upholding the well-being of the MTR, whereas 27.4% showed moderate interest. Only 4.8% expressed disinterest in these conservation efforts. After informing respondents about the challenges facing the MTR and presenting an ongoing plan aimed at its conservation, we queried them about their willingness to allocate a portion of their monthly income to support this proposed plan. Impressively, 64.2% of the surveyed respondents demonstrated a willingness to contribute financially toward the protection and conservation efforts, while the remaining 35.8% expressed unwillingness to do so.Table 4.Respondent Awareness and Willingness to Pay for Enhanced Ecosystem Services in MTR

Threat Perception Based on Garrett’s Ranking Technique

Environmental conservation and the preservation of biodiversity are paramount endeavors, particularly in ecologically sensitive areas such as the Mudumalai Tiger Reserve. This study utilizes Garrett’s Ranking Technique to comprehensively evaluate and rank the challenges faced by the MTR, providing insights into the perspectives of those deeply involved in its conservation efforts. The assessment involved 224 respondents, each offering valuable insights into seven key issues impacting MTR projects. These challenges range from immediate concerns such as forest fires and human–animal conflicts to broader issues such as the impact of a national highway and the proliferation of human settlements. The findings not only shed light on the severity of these challenges but also establish a foundation for well-informed conservation strategies.

Table 5 presents a detailed evaluation of the challenges encountered by the Mudumalai Tiger Reserve using Garrett’s ranking techniques. This method is used to assess the severity of environmental issues associated with the MTR. A total of 224 respondents actively participated in this assessment, contributing their rankings for the seven key problems faced by the MTR. These challenges include forest fires, human–animal conflicts, the presence of a national highway dividing the area, the invasive plant species lantana, the increase in human settlements within the site, overgrazing, and other issues such as poaching, an insufficient number of forest guards, and a rise in the number of hotels. Notably, human–animal conflict emerged as the most pressing concern, receiving the highest mean score of 92.17 from the respondents. Lantana in the site area claimed the second position with a mean value of 62.00, followed by forest fires in the third position with a mean score of 58.44. Overgrazing held the fourth position with a mean value of 56.22, while the presence of a national highway dividing the area ranked fifth with a mean score of 48.00. Increasing human settlements within the site and other miscellaneous issues occupied the sixth and seventh positions, with mean values of 46.33 and 18.07, respectively. Importantly, these problems were not only identified through respondent rankings but were also observed and documented by the researcher during the field survey.Table 5.Challenges Faced by MTR—Garrett’s Ranking Technique.

Logit Regression Analysis

This study utilizes logit regression analysis to examine visitors’ responses in a hypothetical market scenario, based on data from a contingent valuation survey. The dependent variable in this analysis is respondents’ willingness to pay the quoted amount. A value of “1” indicates a willingness to contribute monthly toward Mudumalai conservation, while “0” indicates a lack of willingness to pay. By identifying significant explanatory variables that influence individuals’ decisions regarding willingness to pay, this study offers valuable policy insights and enhances our understanding of respondent behavior. The analysis includes the socio-economic and demographic characteristics of respondents as explanatory variables. Initially, 12 variables were defined for analysis. Correlation matrices were used to identify the influential variables affecting willingness to pay responses. The model assessed multicollinearity, particularly for continuous explanatory variables, using the variance inflation factor (VIF) test. The results showed that multicollinearity was not a significant issue in the model, with VIF values not exceeding 1.82. The final logit regression model included eight explanatory variables: gender, age, family size, respondent’s education, monthly family income, environmental awareness, and bid price. For a comprehensive understanding of parameter estimates and detailed insights into the logit regression analysis results, please refer to Table 6, which presents the analysis outcomes.Table 6.Results of Logit Regression Analysis.Note. The symbols ** and *** denote significance at the 5% and 1% levels, respectively.

Table 6 summarizes the results of the logit regression analysis, highlighting the statistically significant effects of five explanatory variables on WTP: family size, respondent education, monthly family income, environmental awareness, and bid price. Notably, gender and age did not significantly influence on WTP responses. The chi-square value of the coefficients, totaling 127.193, indicates a good fit of the model and the significant predictive capability of the explanatory variables at a 1% significance level. The Nagelkerke R-value of 0.49 suggests a moderately strong relationship between the predictive power of the model and the grouping of data. The overall model’s robust fit is evident in the −2 log-likelihood value of 357.881, achieving an accuracy rate of 77.20% in predicting WTP responses. The use of odd and inverse odds ratios assists in interpreting the logit regression model.

A comprehensive discussion of these findings is crucial for a thorough understanding of their implications. The model highlights the importance of education level, which is treated as a continuous variable, showing a statistically significant positive coefficient at the 1% confidence level. Each additional year of education leads to an approximately 4.03% increase in the likelihood of WTP. This suggests that individuals with higher levels of education are more likely to accept the proposed bid price than those with lower education levels. This is because individuals with higher education have a better understanding of biodiversity decline and the benefits associated with improved ecosystem services. Essentially, education empowers individuals to grasp the consequences of biodiversity loss and ecosystem services decline, enabling them to prioritize benefits that contribute to their health and overall well-being. This positive influence is consistent with previous studies by Baral et al. (2008), Amirnejad et al. (2006), Bee and Selamat (2010), Wang and Jia (2012), Noor et al. (2010), Jaffrey et al. (2012), Hejazi et al. (2014), Bhatt et al. (2014), and Balogh et al. (2016).

Moreover, the impact of family size on the likelihood of WTP for MTR is an important consideration, which was confirmed with high statistical significance at the 1% confidence level. For every one-unit increase in family size, the likelihood of WTP decreases by approximately 10.45%. This suggests that larger families are less likely to participate in the WTP responses. Visitors from larger families tend to have lower WTP than those from smaller families. This trend can be attributed to the increasing expenses and financial responsibilities associated with larger family sizes, which may limit active participation in conservation efforts for families with limited income sources. Essentially, family size has a negative impact on the probability of visitors accepting bids aimed at enhancing ecosystem services. The estimated coefficient for family income, treated as a continuous variable, demonstrates a significant positive relationship with WTP, aligning with economic theory. This relationship is statistically significant at the 1% confidence level. With each unit increase in monthly family income, the likelihood of bidding WTP increases by approximately 0.06%. This suggests that higher-income families are slightly more likely to participate in WTP responses. The positive sign indicates that individuals with higher incomes are more inclined to contribute to ecosystem benefits than those with lower incomes. This is because individuals with greater financial resources are in a better position to benefit from a thriving ecosystem, whereas those with lower incomes may face limitations in accessing such benefits. This finding is consistent with several relevant CVM studies, including the works of Wang and Jia (2012), Ahtiainen (2007), Bhandari and Heshmati (2010), Bhatt et al. (2014), Reynisdottir et al. (2008), Adekunle et al. (2012), Seongseop et al. (2007), Samdin et al. (2010), Togridou et al. (2006), Skeie et al. (2019), and Zambrano-Monserrate (2020).

Similarly, the coefficient for environmental awareness, presented as a categorical dummy variable, has a discernible positive impact on WTP responses, establishing statistical significance at the 1% confidence level. Individuals with a higher level of environmental consciousness regarding the challenges faced by the MTR region are more likely to contribute significantly to the enhancement of ecosystem services through the preservation of the MTR. Environmental awareness positively influences WTP, with a 19.13% increase in the likelihood of WTP for each unit increase in environmental awareness. This means that individuals who are more environmentally aware are more likely to participate in WTP responses than their less-aware counterparts, who are less inclined to make such contributions. The likelihood of visitors endorsing or declining a bid price often depends on the value of the bid itself. Budgetary constraints play a major role in households’ consumption choices, making them an important factor in the decision-making process. Additionally, the coefficient of the bid price shows a negative correlation with WTP responses, with a confidence level of 1%. For every increase in the bid price, there is a decrease in approximately 1.2% in the likelihood of WTP. This suggests that higher bid prices may discourage individuals from participating in WTP responses. This also indicates that as bid values decrease, the probability of respondents responding positively to the bid price increases. This finding aligns with economic theory, which states that the likelihood of accepting a bid price tends to increase as the bid price decreases. These findings are consistent with economic demand theory and are supported by other CVM studies, including Adamowicz et al. (1994), Loomis et al. (2000), Baral et al. (2008), Lockwood and Tracy (1995), Mohd Rusli et al. (2009), and Reynisdottir et al. (2008).

Conclusion and Policy Implications

The Mudumalai Tiger Reserve is currently facing significant challenges, largely driven by negative externalities and drivers of ecosystem change. As a result, there is a risk to the ecological balance and the provision of crucial ecosystem services. This study examined to examine the factors that influence visitors’ willingness to pay for the conservation of MTR and the improvement of ecosystem services, using the dichotomous choice contingent valuation method. In addition, visitor preferences and concerns regarding conservation initiatives were explored, with a focus on measuring WTP through changes in probability. The findings of this study have important implications. It was revealed that a substantial portion of the surveyed visitors were genuinely concerned about mitigating the adverse impacts on MTR and were willing to provide financial support for ecosystem preservation and enhancement. This alignment with human well-being is encouraging and signifies a positive attitude toward conservation efforts. Moreover, various socio-demographic, economic, and environmental factors were found to significantly influence individuals’ inclination to make financial contributions. Specifically, education level, monthly family income, and environmental awareness were positively associated with willingness to pay response. Conversely, family size and the proposed bid price were found to have a negative impact on the likelihood of a WTP response.

Policy Implications

Based on these findings, several policy recommendations are proposed to enhance ecosystem benefits and address challenges in tiger conservation within the MTR.

Education and Awareness Programs

Given the significance of education and environmental awareness in influencing visitors’ willingness to pay, it is crucial that policymakers prioritize the development and implementation of educational and awareness programs. These initiatives should enhance public understanding of the ecological importance of MTR and the benefits that come from conserving ecosystems. Possible avenues for integrating these programs include school curricula, visitor information centers, and community outreach initiatives.

Income-Linked Pricing Strategies

The findings of this study suggest that visitors with higher family incomes are more likely to contribute to conservation efforts. Therefore, policymakers should consider implementing income-linked pricing strategies, such as differential entrance fees or donation structures. These strategies can capitalize on the higher willingness to pay of economically advantaged visitors, thus generating additional revenue for conservation activities.

Family-Centric Engagement

This study highlights the influence of family size on willingness to pay, suggesting that larger families may face financial constraints when contributing to conservation efforts. To address this, policymakers can implement family-centric engagement programs, such as group discounts, family-oriented educational activities, and targeted fundraising initiatives. These measures encourage participation and support from larger family units.

Dynamic Pricing Strategies

The study’s findings indicate that implementing dynamic pricing strategies for ecotourism activities in the MTR could optimize conservation funding. This approach allows visitors to contribute directly to conservation efforts and align their WTP with the reserve’s funding needs. It also offers visitors a way to express their support for conservation.

Mitigating Human–Wildlife Conflict

This study emphasizes human–wildlife conflict as a significant concern in the MTR. To address this issue, policymakers and reserve management should prioritize targeted interventions, including effective land-use planning, establishment of wildlife corridors, and promotion of sustainable agricultural practices that minimize negative interactions between humans and wildlife.

By implementing these policy recommendations, researchers, managers, and policymakers can collaborate to enhance ecosystem services in the MTR and other Indian tiger reserves. This collaborative effort will benefit both the local community and the conservation of these vital ecosystems. In conclusion, it is evident that visitors to the MTR hold a positive attitude toward conservation endeavors. By understanding the complex relationship between socioeconomic and demographic factors, conservation and management initiatives can be tailored to be inclusive, fair, and sustainable. Policymakers can enhance ecosystem benefits and address the challenges in tiger conservation within the reserve by implementing policy suggestions that prioritize education, awareness, the mitigation of human–wildlife conflict, and income-linked and dynamic pricing strategies.

Gaps and Future Research Directions

While this study sheds light on the determinants of visitors’ willingness to pay in the MTR, there are areas for future research. For example, investigating the perspectives and behaviors of local communities and other stakeholders would complement the study’s focus on visitors’ willingness to pay. Additionally, further research could explore the effectiveness of targeted environmental education programs in shaping conservation attitudes and behaviors, considering the study’s findings on the influence of environmental awareness and education. Finally, more research is needed to develop and evaluate specific interventions to mitigate human–wildlife conflict and enhance coexistence between humans and wildlife in the MTR.

urn:contentItem:67CR-H1B1-F0J6-J3RG-00000-00Reminder to stay vigilant ahead of Australia Day2023-01-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:49:08ZLexisNexisReminder to stay vigilant ahead of Australia Day

Fire authorities are urging residents to be careful around campfires and barbecues as Australia Day and the end of summer holidays approach.

The Conservation Regulator, Parks Victoria, Forest Fire Management Victoria and the County Fire Authority have all teamed together and urge anyone lighting a campfire to be vigilant.

CFA chief officer Jason Heffernan said in recent weeks the weather had been heating up and grass had dried out considerably.

"I urge all Victorians ahead of this weekend to check the Fire Danger Ratings and to heed our warnings before heading out and about," he said in a statement.

La Nina weather has encouraged grass growth over the spring and summer.

Regional Ballarat council areas, including Pyrenees and Golden Plains shires, have reported some areas are still too wet to slash.

IN THE NEWS:

Historic cottage to go for dual townhouses under new planning application La Trobe Street intersection works enter final stages Homegrown talent stays on with Miners Forest Fire Management Victoria crews have already responded to 96 unattended campfires on public land this summer.

An unattended campfire could escape and cause larger fires.

Forest Fire Management Victoria chief fire officer Chris Hardman said a fire should be cool to touch before you leave.

"Just one spark from an unattended campfire is enough to have devastating consequences," he said.

Keep watch during hot days: Use your charcoal burner in a clear space. Never dispose of or handle old coals until they are completely cold. In state forests: use a purpose-built fireplace or dig a trench at least 30cm deep. In national parks: fires can only be lit in purpose-built fireplaces. Never leave a campfires unattended - always stay within line of sight. Have you tried The Courier's app? It can be downloaded here.
